number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												This is one game I am glad I accidently stumbled across. The Dark Forces/Jedi Knight is the beginning of one of the most enjoyable SW series of games available on PC, and its roots are still worth looking into.The Canon Solution: Ignition Start, Soar Elsewhere UnexploredWe all are aware of the recent trend of SW games being tied to the SW canon. A lot of these games, as a result, feel worthless in their stories as we all know what happens whether or not we play the game. It also has the unfortunate side-effect of making the player ask, "So? Why should I care?" about these spin-off stories that don't do anything different.Dark Forces only brings the canon to give context (time and place) at the start, then lets the story go on its own territory with its own cast of characters. The first mission is to steal the Death Star plans (Ep 4).  After that introduction, the game leaves the canon behind for Kyle's Kataran's story. You are on a mission to stop a mysterious project for the Empire called Dark Troopers. The plot is bare-bones, but the character progression fits the SW universe.Kyle Kataran, a combination of all the lovable qualities of Han Solo and Luke Skywalker. He was once an Imperial Officer. As you learn throughout the game, he went rogue and performs duties with the Rebel Alliance--for a certain price, of course, or sometimes out of his own generosity. Kyle is a simple character, but he becomes more interesting in later games (not simply for being a Jedi). For an introduction to Kyle Katarn, it's interesting to see how a non-Jedi character can play a vital role in the rebellion from the Empire, especially for the Doom-esque genre.Not only are the characters memorable, the atmosphere in this game is perfect. Sometimes dark and claustrophobic, other times laybrinthlike and open to exploration (and there is a lot! I never found all the secrets in any of the stages). While there isn't a complex story-arc, the story is servicable to add some depth. I only find this interesting as this was always something lacking for me whenever I play Doom or Duke Nukem 3D.Aim Somewhere Between Doom and Duke Nukem 3DThe controls are top-notch despite being a Doom clone with no free-aiming. The only issue, which you don't have to use often because of auto-aiming, is tilting the screen up with the Page DOWN key and tilt the screen down with Page UP key. (Who programed this nonsense?)In missions 3 - 6 there were some pretty cryptic nonsense that will aggrivate you, but the later puzzles are beatable with enough perception--I liked the puzzle on the Imperial City that I figured out alone. Enemies are nicely varied, there are tons of weapons that feel, mostly, different and the maps are HUGE. Bosses, like most FPSs, are pretty lackluster and just require you to spam your heaviest weapons and to dodge their attacks. They are somewhat specatular or given some context to make them feel more threatening than other enemies.Levels consist of completing certain objectives and either returning to the LZ at the start, which can be tricky to find for some levels, or heading for some exit. The only level I despised for its maze-like quality is the Prison level, but the others feel expansive enough and meaty to serve for enough gameplay. There are some other old-fashioned quirks that you have to adjust to in order to enjoy this game. Besides the resolution and sprite-work which, for the most part, looks great when up-close but a pixely mess from afar.The first is the "lives" system. Die several times, you lose the mission and you have to start over. You cannot quicksave mid-mission (only after it). The lives system reminds me an awful like Rise of the Triad as you can earn more through finding tokens or you can earn a 1-up with enough points. And similar to RotT, there are SOME platforming sections. Nowhere near the amount of platform issues as with RotT; they just feel out of place for the game. Lastly, some guns share ammo, so be wary of using the same ammo type.This is no push-over of a game. The difficulty doesn't feel as difficult as NIGHTMARE mode on Doom, but I remember toning it down on the later levels because of how often I got lost or frustrated because of the lives' system. I don't think the difficulty should be a concern of yours unless you've never played a Doom-like game before.Only The Beginning...As the start of a well-loved series, this game is a classic mired by problems within the FPSs of the time. Sure, it doesn't do anything new, gameplay wise, but what it does it does well along with the treatment of the SW lore done right. These qualities make it a worthy game as the gameplay works and the story keeps you engaged to play more.You will feel like you are a flickering flame of rebellion fighting an oppresive threat that has its hold on the Galaxy. With each new challenge you must adapt to new enemies and locales. And in the end you don't defeat the Empire; you make it aware that its ending reign is on the horizon.How can you not love this true-to-heart Star Wars game?Unless you're a hipster.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Even though I haven't played this in 20 years it's probably better than I imagined.  So many nostalgia unleashed from playing, from enemies to sounds, parts of levels, entire levels.  Some was better than I remembered and some mainly just from a graphical stand point was a lot worse.  If you like star wars and can get past dated graphics this is a great game.  If you like shooters like doom 1/2 or wolfenstein 3d or duke dukem 3d then you will like this game.  Nice level design, pretty damn easy on easy, medium was met with a challenge.  I found myself repeating some levels and sometimes getting stuck.  I could play a level for over an hour, be stuck on something, die and come back and beat it again in 10 minutes, so there were some frustrating momemts, but overall a goood game.8/10prosStar WarsNice level designFamiliar enemies and places10 weapons is a lot for even games that are released todayPretty good storyconsold- things such as graphics are lesser, or things that would be impressive, such as having cutscenes and  objectives which weren't the norm back then, are now.enemy variety could have been moreif you don't get as stuck like me, its a bit short at only 12 or 13 missionsIf you love star wars or old school fps buy full price.  If you love star wars and have issues with bad graphics get it on sale.

												first off i just want to say that this is a very odd star trek game it seem to parodize the star wars franchise in the beginning with the return of a phantom hope theme song and the rolling text which i by the way wasnt able to read because it was rolling too fast and because yellow is such a bright color and it made my eyes hurtthe first enemny you meet also kind of looks like a stormshgooter but the sprites are so low-res that its impossible to tellthe first thing i noticed about the gameplay is that you can walk in every direction and look both left and right which is a good thing because you will need to be able look both sides to be able to complete the gamehowever what i didn't like about the gameplay is that instead of scripted jump events you can just jump whenever you feel like it and that kind of ruined the immersion for me..... i mean jumping around liike a looney toons character isint going to kill any klingons.... what were you thinking gorge lucas?????the shooting however is the best i've ever seen in a cover based first person dungeon crawlerthe develoeprs of this game knw that people dont really want to aim.... they want shoot lazers and look cool while doing itsecrets is abig part of the game there are so many secrets in the game i dont know where to begin sometimes if you nlow up a wall and sometimes you can find another weapon that shoots a different kind of laser and that is kind of c00lthere are also more levels than i have fingers that is really neat \m/something i really dont like about this game however is that there arent that many klingons in the game and when there are they have 3 eyes and all they do is to throw grenades @ you.... i expected more from them tbh i also didnt like the lack of waist-height obstacles to take cover behind......... that is very importatn 4 this type of gamehowever...... even if this is a very odd star trek game i would recommend it because there are so many things to shoot at

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Now, I know what you're thinking. You see the red thumbs down and you think I'm going to complain about how this game is old.No. This is an enjoyable game. It is not a bad game by any means. However, it is true that it is old. It has aged, pretty badly in some parts. The reason I am not recommending this game is because there are much better games out there on Steam that can be bought for $6. Hell, you can buy the original Deus Ex for just $7, and that's one of the best games ever made, hands down.It really depends on how much you're going to enjoy the game. If you have played this game back in the day, and you have nostalgia for it, it might be worth the price. However, for me, who hasn't played this game until 2014, it wouldn't have been worth it. I got this game in the Jedi Knight Bundle, so I don't feel like I've wasted any money. Overall, I would only reccomend this game to the nostalgic, and even then, they probably own it already. To everyone else, I would say no, due to the abundance of better alternatives for the same cost. Even then, I recommend saving up to get some of the better games on Steam, like GTA V, MGS V, or Deus Ex.EDIT: It says that I have less than an hour into the game, but that's because I mostly played the game through the XL engine. I have about 1 or 2 hours into this game, I believe.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Maybe this game used to be great in the hey days of 2.5D FPSs, but to me it feels more dated than Doom or Duke Nuke'Em 3D. While those other titles seemed to have pixel-perfect, artist made sprites; the sprites Dark Forces appear to get their basis from scanned photos and retain that muddled, pixelated look. Another fault is there are so many grey walls with low resolution textures that it is easy to get lost in the levels due to the lack of recognizable landmarks. I am sure that die-hard fans of old-school FPSs or Star Wars will find a lot to like, but for me I'd rather skip this and move on to Jedi Knight 2, which has both the better visual representation of SW and better gameplay.

												I still remember walking into a EB to get this game when it was called Cabbages in my area.  I saw this on the shelf and I begged my Mother with all the power I could muster. This is Golden Age LucasArts at it's finest.  I still pull out the old Pentium Pro system to play this game.  Highly recommend with DarkXL Mod.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I hate Star Wars. I just don't get it. I find the films dreary, dull and unwatchable, and certainly can't understand the intensity people rave about them. The merchandise produced alone is enough to bury the Matterhorn, and frankly I couldn't care who shot first. There you go. Click the 'downvote' button and move on.I love this game though. Superficially it feels similar to the "Blood"-era BUILD engine, with the lightness of movement and spacious surroundings, but it's very well constructed. The levels are interesting, logical and practical. The puzzles are slightly more interesting than "use red key on red door", the AI isn't bad for it's time, and the graphics and sound are top-notch. If you like old-style FPSes, you can't go wrong with Dark Forces.I'll skip the cut-scenes though, if you don't mind.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I remember playing this game back on the PS1. The main character is a badass who works as a Merc for the Rebellion. Due to this flexibility, he isn't a main part of the alliance, but he certainly perfers it then working for the empire.The story to this game is you play as this character during the events of Star Wars Episode IV, and V I believe, it has been a while since I completed this game. The first mission involves you doing something none of the other Rebel Infiltraitor's had done, retrieve the blueprints to the death star. As any Star Wars fan knows, the plans are what revealed a weak point in the Death Star's defences and the leader even mentioned how they lost many men attempting to get that information.You are then called in because a Rebel base when silent from an attack, but this was no ordinary attack as the entire base was taken out and if it was a army, they would've seen it coming and evacuated or atleast shot many of them down before going into hiding. It's then revealed that one of the most interesting enemies of the Star Wars franchile is created here. The Dark Troopers. Commando Troopers that are far more powerful and destructive than you're average trooper as they can take out entire complexs by themselves.Many weapons you get are references to the ones from the film such as blaster pistol, blaster rifle, Thermal Detonator and quite a few interesting and creative weapon designs.It's well worth a play if you can get a hang of the controls and remember how Lucas Arts used to make years ago as this was during the age they made adventure games and before they went lax and started making half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥games.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												I felt kind of odd recommending every single game I own and finish here, so before you take this review as a big strong NO, accept it in the context of my library – if there is one game in my library I would not recommend thus far, it would be this one. It’s not because of technical issues or my hate of the game, I actually quite like it, but since I played it before, I’ve decided to play it on hard this time around and it revealed a couple of issues this game gained by aging very, very poorly. First off, the controls. The look up and down buttons are mapped somewhere to the numpad and thus every instance of looking up or down turns into an ordeal. It’s especially annoying when an enemy surprises you by standing on a heightened platform or straight under you, because you learn about it the painful way and before you can react accordingly by adjusting the view, your shield is dropping like vases in cartoons. There’s no in-game ability to remap the keys either. What’s more surprising – no mid-level saves, so screw up right before the end and prepare to rage quit. Now before you think of me as some amateur noob, let me assure you that that’s a thing that crossed my mind as well. But there’s challenging and then there’s straight broken ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. So if there is a turret placed on the ceiling of a maintenance tunnel/ventilation duct, doesn’t make a warning sound and is able to blast your bum from here to Tatooine with spotless accuracy, that’s just bad game design. When a mine blows my jacket straight off, because the only warning of its position behind a crate is a short beeping sound signaling that I just entered a domain of pain, I would enjoy at least a single checkpoint. This game is not a Doom clone, despite looking like one. It’s packed with ambitious innovation, which is alas very poorly implemented. And if you turn the difficulty up in Doom, that game at least has the decency to lift you off the tracks after shoving you under a train. This game, on the other hand, will shoot your kneecaps as soon as you scramble back onto your feet. And if you don’t plan on playing this game on hard, or conversely at least don’t mind putting your face to a cheese grater, then you may just enjoy this old fossil.

content:

This is the game as it was released back in '95. I didn't play it back then, so non-nostalgic commentary.It runs on DOSbox and is build upon Doom, so the controls, movement, environment, enemies and pickups look the same. But Dark Forces has a slightly better graphic, additionally voice acting and cut-scenes. All of these are remarkable for the year of release.Sadly I am not recommending this game because I couldn't pass through mission 2 (also had trouble on mission 1), even though I tried for sometime. It's not intuitive, after activating a lever/button you simply don't know where to go. Places sometimes feels like mazes. If the problem was a puzzle or a riddle I could have looked for a walkthrough, but needing it to continue a game's storyline is a lack of level building.If nostalgia hits you, take it, this game wasn't touched by the time. If you want a first person Star Wars shooter, leave it, there are better.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												I LOOOOOVED this game in 1995.  It was the first thing I bought with my first paycheck when I turned 16 that year.  I love star wars, and I love doom.  Except this game had a better plot, cutscenes to support it, and some nifty tricks like jumping, crouching, and looking up and down.  Due to the last of those, the level design is genius!  You really have to explore, as keys are often hidden in little side areas rather than be guarded by groups of MOBs.  Back then it looked amazing, although 20 years later not as much.  Although, the graphics are really not all that necessary, as those mid 90's FPS's are all about gameplay and level design.  I miss this.  I cannot stand FPS games where basic enemies are bullet sponges.  I get bored if I have to put 8 or more rounds in every basic enemy.  These games are more "realistic" in the fact that you can clear the guards out of an area to perform your espionage, with a few well placed blaster rounds.  Only droids and hearty aliens like Gamorreans.  You may even get to punch a Kell Dragon to death ;).  The introduction of Kyle Katarn and the whole Jedi Knight series does not play like the followups.  He is not a jedi, and you get no lightsaber.  However, at this time period in Star Wars lore, the amount of Jedi is down to a couple tops, including a couple geriatrics and a 19 year old kid.  Getting to play a part in the rebellion to help dismantle the Empire is pretty cool for any Star Wars fan, and the gameplay will satisfy any retro FPS fan.  I do recommend looking into the XL engine.  It is a free fan made sourceport, currently in alpha.  It runs the game pretty well, and makes it much easier on a modern gamer.  Full mouselook, right click to use, and an overall refresh of the graphics.  Just textures, no new models or anything, but since the Jedi engine is not released, the guy had to build a new engine.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Dark Forces was a groundbreaking game back in the day.It was an FPS that wasn't about just finding a switch at the end of a level to move onto the next level. The enemies were actually varied and different strategies were required in the levels.The visuals were amazing, and the sound was incredible.As you might expect, the standard for all of these things has increased monumentally, so this title isn't quite the media spectacle it once was. It's probably not even worth playing through again, even if you have fond memories of it as it has not stood the test of time very well. But at least it can still be remembered for laying the foundation for the first-person shooters of today.4/10 "Poor"

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I got this game during a star wars sale and was excited to see some of the earlier lore. I've enjoyed it some, but overall its just a bit irritating. Like some other people have said, "you will get lost very easily" and when you get to mission X I will be surprised if you find yourself doing anything other than talking angrily at your computer screen. This game serves as a prime example of many elements in games that developers had yet to smooth out (and no, I don't just mean that its old; there are problems with more than the limits of the days technology). As soon as the implementation of mines starts this game moves from possibly difficult to punishing and you will find that you have to remember things about the levels and replay them to move on with the story. I would only recommend this game if you love Star wars and don't mind being frustrated and having to be persistent or use cheats (at least supposing that you like to play games on hard mode like I do).

What I liked:  That it allowed the Jedi Knight series to be madeWhat You Need to Know:  This game is run through DOSBox, meaning it plays 100% like the original. If your like me and need it to be modern, with aiming and better settings. Download this mod XL Engine: 


Getting started with XL Engine 
A Guide for STAR WARS™: Dark Forces
By: MagicDN

			Playing Star Wars: Dark Forces with widescreen and Full HD support.		


 I don’t mind old games if you can fix the old issues, I loved Brutal Doom, so old games can age well if designed well. Dark Forces sucks in almost every way compared to most Doom clones unless you’re a super fan of star wars The levels are expansive and layered and I bet at the time this was cool, but this just makes the game tedious to travel as it takes a while to around as it’s easy to get lost This games has puzzles per level that aren’t hard to solve, it just requires pushing a lot of buttons in an area that aren’t hard and just break up the fighting, The first 2 ones were lame and I couldn’t push myself to care to finish if this is what the game had in store The weapons are mostly laser rifles and I think this shows a problem in the star wars universe that if all weapons are laser rifles it’s hard to mix it up. I got the blue laser rifle and laughed as it wasn’t better or served a different purpose than my storm trooper rifle. LOL The environments look nice and the story has cutscenes that are a treat for fans of the star wars lore. Overall I might be able to understand when this came out it was cool, but after playing the Jedi Knight series, it does everything this game can’t. Maybe I played them out of order. Regardless this game is poorly designed and that's something even mods can't fix My Score: DPaid: Included in $12 Humble BundleMain reason for dislike: The puzzles were tedious, pointless and weapons are lame Similar Games I think are Better:  Duke Nukem Shadow Warrior Strife Jedi Knight 1 & 2 (the best star wars style games)

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Before i write this review  i wanted to say i wasn't sure if i should give it a positive or negative review. Obviously, by today's standards, this is a terrible game. But you also have to take into consideration that it was made in 1995. So it certinly wasn't going to be great. So, I'm going to write about some of the good and bad things about this game, I only gave it a negative review because i enjoyed many games made in the 90's. This game, however, is not one of them. The only reason I bought this game was because of how much I loved Dark Forces II, So i figured I would enjoy this game just as much. But they're both completely different games. First off: You will get lost VERY easily. There's never any clear indication as to where you're supposed to go. You do have a map but that really doesn't help. So you'll spend the majority of each level wandering around and going a bunch of places that don't lead anywhere. The game is also pretty easy combat wise. You'll almost never die, (although, i did only play the game in medium difficuilty) All you'll do is see something move and just hold down the left mouse button until he dies in one or two shots. It;s also a bit confusing at first. When i had completed all my objectives it didn't take me to the next level. Confused, i just wandered around for awhile figuring i had to find an exit. After awhile, i got a message saying i had to pause the game and click next mission. This was more than likely my fault i'll admit. It probably sent me that message as soon as i finished all my objectives when i wasn't paying attention. But it's still odd and confusing. It actually has a pretty good atmosphere. At one point it was even pretty creepy. During the second level you have to go down this water drain and you'll end up in this really dark room in waist high sewage water. After i walked around for awhile i heard a sort of growl. It actually creeped me out quite a bit. As i continued i heard more growls but i still couldn't see anything. Until, finally, i ran smack dab into this octopus looking creature that emerged from the water my immediate response was to hold down my fire button until it died. It was actually quite jarring. All-In-All, It wasn't a horrible game, it's just not a game for most people. If you like games like DOOM then you'll probably enjoy this game. But, if you're just a fan of Star Wars or just saw this and it looked interesting. I would suggest not buying it.

number of helpful: 13 of 42 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Star Wars: Dark Forces is pretty much Doom: Star Wars Edition. You're thinking "That's great then! What's the problem then?". Well, a lot actually...The story starts off with a defect from the sith empire stealing the death star plans for the Rebel alliance, setting itself up for what starts off tieing in to Episode IV: A New Hope, but then goes off in it's own direction, including Dark Troopers as the Siths new method of ruling the galaxy, and you, the defect, have to stop them. Nice idea for a story, but the dialogue is so corny it's difficult to take seriously.The core gameplay is Doom in a nutshell. Running around what are pretty much mazes, blasting stormtroopers that can hit something and occasionally collecting keys to open doors you found earlier that you couldn't open, with the occasional mediocre puzzle thrown in... and that's pretty much it. Backtracking is far too common in this game, which is a let down, and the platforming... Don't get me started on how bad that was...The sound effects that we all know and love from Star Wars are there (no Wilhelm Scream though...) and the music we all know and love is there as well, including the music played during the Death Star attack from Episode IV.One final note: Why did I have to look online for the controls to this game? Why wasn't there an option to access the controls ANYWHERE in the game? It would have helped me out in the first 4 or 5 missions. Playing around with the Gamma Correction in the options menu and shooting was not what I wanted to do to navigate dark areas thanks.It's by no means the worst Star Wars game, but it's definitely not the best. However, it was definitely a bad start for the Jedi Knight series and not worth your time, unless you're a diehard Star Wars fan.

Posted: June 3, 2014
												10/10 you can jumpIt really is a good game if you like Star Wars and old school FPS games like Doom and Wolfenstein 3D. The game is about Kyle Katarn who steals the Death Star plans in the beginning. Afterwards it skips past A New Hope and goes into it's own story where the Empire introduce their Dark Trooper Project. The graphics aren't too great but that's not too important, plus it's old and they were good for their time. Gameplay is good and it's pretty much Doom except, as I mentioned before, U CEN JUMP 2PRO and it's also one of the first games to feature multiple floors. Overall if you like old school shooters and Star Wars I recommend the game.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												As much as I like to lament the rise of the linear, corridor shooter, Dark Forces' level design is a proper counter argument to the growing sentiment that Doom-era level design was inherently superior. The environments' visual simularity makes it hard to differentiate areas you've already explored and the maps sprawl and twist with hidden nooks and crannies that, in most games, would be secret areas but, here, are necessary to find and explore to progress.If this sounds like it's going to be a negative review, I've misled you. Complaints on level design aside, the story is pretty great, especially for a shooter from this era, and the gameplay is challenging and frenetic at times. Your movement speed is akin to an F1 car and the weapons are satisfying in a Doom rocket launcher sorta way. Blasters shoot with violent rapidity and mowing down stormtroopers doesn't get old quickly.I played through the entire campaign on medium when it was new (I'm old), and played through about half of it on easy here. On easy, I would finish most levels with max armor and health, on medium I remember things getting hairy a few times.Worth it for nostalgia if you played it the first time and for morbid curiosity if you've never kicked the tires.It's hard to imagine playing everything at this game's resolution back in the day. Such pixels.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												How can you not love this classic?  A brilliant FPS in the Star Wars universe that introduced us to Kyle Katarn.  It can feel a bit dated when you play it and it takes a bit to get used to not being able to look up and down with the mouse but the game is packed with interesting, challenging (and occasionally frustrating) puzzles.  The story is also fantastic and for its time the game did a good job with the music and sound.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to play a game that's poorly structured, devoid of real action, strays from the main events which can be found within the history of the Star Wars universe, and lacks the ability to make the player (especially one who harbours feelings of such great affection and admiration towards the Star Wars franchise in its entirety) feel nostalgic? Well, if so, don't purchase this game, because, if you're seeking any of the above traits, you're sure to be disappointed - Star Wars: Dark Forces, is an exceptional work of game design. Though it is, in fact, the case that the game's graphics aren't of an overly high quality by the standards of the gamers of today's society, I can say that, despite this, it is still quite an impressive game; the various methods of, shall we say, "neutralizing" hostile units are all quite entertaining, and, though the game may be slightly old, the movement within the game on the part of the character is remarkably smooth. Never have I once found movement to be even the slightest bit, "laggy", no matter how vigorous my travelling has become. Look, I'm not saying this game is great - I'm just saying it's awesome considering the sale price, and that, for this, and numerous other reasons which I won't even begin to attempt to list, you should definitely buy it.

Posted: April 21, 2014
												Hey, everyone! This is my first review and I'm brazilian, so I'm sorry in advance for any grammar mistakes.Dark Forces I is a First Person Shooter developed by Lucasarts, it came out in 1995. In this game, the player takes control of Kyle Katarn, gun for hire and ex-imperial officer. I'm not sure if this game is canon, but we find out how the Death Star plans were stolen from the Galactic Empire - that's the first mission, setting the stage for Episode IV. After Katarn steals the plans and the Death Star is destroyed, the Empire develops a new weapon to unleash against it's enemies, and it's up to Katarn to investigate and neutralize the threat. One curiosity about it is that Dark Forces I is the game that introduced the ability to jump and look up and down.My time with Dark Forces can be divided into three distinct eras: After it came out, my parents bought the cd for me to play. I found the concept of FPS - it was one of the first shooters I ever played, along with Doom and Wolfenstein 3D (the first game I beat) - very fun and interesting, and I'd already seen the classic trilogy. Shoot imperials, blow up facilities? Sounds fun! I was very little (seven or eight, I think), and I used the in-game "cheat" which can be acessed in the options submenu: super shields. I didn't know that it was some kind of cheat, so I thought the game was too easy. The third level was difficult, but I managed. Until the sixth level. There was no way I could figure that puzzle out - I didn't even know there was a puzzle - and, after some game rage, I went to real cheat codes. Ah, the scum and villainy... I beat the game like that, using super shields and level skip whenever I got stuck.In the second era, some good six years later, I was determined to beat all levels, but still using cheat codes - ah, the scum and villainy II -. I finally figured the puzzle out - didn't take long - and I felt really dumb. Was I a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ kid? Maybe.And we come to the final era. I've decided to give this game another try, this time without any cheat codes, and on hard difficulty. Not surprisingly, I died a few times, especially against some certain kell dragons. Damn it, that was hard. But I did it, and I for certain recommend this game, for nostalgic reasons, to see how the First Person Shooters evolved and to see how Kyle Katarn began his journey!

Posted: August 29, 2014
												Ancient Proto-FPS. This prequel to the Jedi Knight series is basically like Doom or Wolfenstein, but with Stormtroopers. You play as Kyle Katarrn, before he becomes a Jedi. You basically just infiltrate various Imperial Installations and blast things. The story is all breezy, and involves espionage for the Rebel Alliance, mostly about the Death Star, in advance of the plot of the first Star Wars (the real first one, not Episode 1). That's about it. The game is too terribly long, but not too short either. Basically get it if you enjoy nostalgia, both in Star Wars EU and very early shooters, and it is on-sale cheap, or part of a pack.

Posted: April 14, 2016
												I used to play this for the original Playstation back in the day. I enjoy it even more now, than I did back then. It's amusing trying to play it without being able to look up or down, but other than that it plays pretty decently for a game that's as old as it is. All Star Wars fans would enjoy it, I think, especially if you enjoy the EU/Legends-verse (or whatever they're calling it these days) This was the first game in a strong series, starring the (at the time) mysterious Kyle Katarn. You're sent on missions to help the Rebels, you get to shoot at Imperials, and you even get a sidekick! Though sadly, she doesn't actually accompany you on the missions. A game I've been able to play over and over again and am happy to finally own on Steam as well.

Posted: April 14, 2016
												Runs fine on Win10...  So far I have had it running on an AMD64 (64b OS) and an intel atom platform (32b OS) - both Windows 10.  If you have issues with it crashing at start - make sure you have both dosbox and dark.exe (in your dark forces folder) set to compatility mode.  WinXPSP3 was used for my systems.  first try to start dosbox by itself - see that it runs.  You might even try to invoke dark forces by typing:mount c ..\Gamec:dark.exe  if the game runs then you can go from there and start editing the dosbox.conf file - first make a copy of the .conf file.  Then remove cpu=xxxxxx and also remove exit (last line in the file).  Additionally, change "game" to ..\Game (case sensitive just in case).    Once the game starts up - it may run exceedingly fast.  That's where you can go back to the conf file and re-introduce the cpu=xxxxxxx line to its original value.  If the game still runs entirely TOO fast, increase the left most digit of that number (originally 20000).  Hey - this game was released over 20 YEARS ago.  I wouldn't expect it to run flawlessly on every platform or the latest OS and processors today, considering it was made for x86 DOS platforms way back when processors were 133MHz single core and a math coprocessor was a luxury!  Hopefully that helps....Of all the new FPS games that were being released in the mid 90s, DARK FORCES shines as something that incorporated a good storyline with an anti-hero.  Several levels required a bit of thinking, a bit of skill, and plenty of storm trooper fights.  Additionally the build up of some of the big bosses were great - sometimes very tense.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												As much as I like to lament the rise of the linear, corridor shooter, Dark Forces' level design is a proper counter argument to the growing sentiment that Doom-era level design was inherently superior. The environments' visual simularity makes it hard to differentiate areas you've already explored and the maps sprawl and twist with hidden nooks and crannies that, in most games, would be secret areas but, here, are necessary to find and explore to progress.If this sounds like it's going to be a negative review, I've misled you. Complaints on level design aside, the story is pretty great, especially for a shooter from this era, and the gameplay is challenging and frenetic at times. Your movement speed is akin to an F1 car and the weapons are satisfying in a Doom rocket launcher sorta way. Blasters shoot with violent rapidity and mowing down stormtroopers doesn't get old quickly.I played through the entire campaign on medium when it was new (I'm old), and played through about half of it on easy here. On easy, I would finish most levels with max armor and health, on medium I remember things getting hairy a few times.Worth it for nostalgia if you played it the first time and for morbid curiosity if you've never kicked the tires.It's hard to imagine playing everything at this game's resolution back in the day. Such pixels.

												Incredibly addicting. It's actually a poop-ton of fun, if not just a bit aggravating. Levels are pretty good length, and there is no saving your game, except between missions. You are on a life system, meaning every level, you get three lives to finish the level. Usually not a problem, but the game isn't always easy. In fact there are times where I felt like some levels were just cheap at times (but extremely well-designed). For being the launching point for some of my very fvorite star wars games (jedi knight 2 and jedi academy), I absolutely recommend this game.Graphics 8/10, i guess? I hve no idea what the standard should be, but it's certainly good enough if you at least understand that you're playing a DOS game. Gameplay 8/10 Cool levels and puzzle like design, but gunplay is tough and some areas are littered with invisible minefields that just feel kinda cheap. Make sure ou grab the infrared goggles. Story 7/10 It's alright, but I bet it's downright impressive next to other games' stories of it's time. Lasting appeal: 9/10 I mean, 14 missions, took me a total of 23 hours to complete the game, which is a pretty good length. It's just fun, and for the price, it's well worth your time.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												A dinosaur for the die hard Star Wars gamer.My early childhood memories include playing this game with my older brother for hours on end back in the day but I can safely say that nostalgia alone is not the reason why I've continued to replay this game every now and then. While this game is simply old as dirt it offers a fresh and interesting experience the likes of which are rarely seen within the Jedi obsessed nature of nearly every other Star Wars game.You'll play as the mercenary Kyle Kattarn who gets the job done by the skin of his teeth. Relying solely on weapons fire and cunning to accomplish his missions rather than a swing of a lightsaber or force powers. Levels are similar to those seen in the older Doom, Duke Nukem or Marathon games where you'll explore secret Imperial military bases and the lairs of seedy underworld criminals in service of the then fledgling Rebel Alliance.While I can't promise that this game will sit well in most gamer's stomachs it will easily become a favorite to those who love dipping in to the past. For those gamers I highly recommend buying this old school title immediately.

Posted: February 12, 2016
												Star Wars - Doom, Doom: Star Wars... no matter how you would call it, Dark Forces is really amazing game.Dark Forces wasn't my first Star Wars game. Played it for first time probably around Star Wars Episode 1 film premiere because it made to want to play everything with "Star Wars" in name. The only thing I was wondering when I will got lightsaber and have some cool Jedi fights but at the time, sadly, I was disappointed to see that I won't use one in this game. Many years later, in 2016, I wanted to replay it. To be honest, when it would be my first time playing, I would stop playing it few times. Why? First of all, nowaday gamers will have trouble finding their way to finish missions. Levels in Dark Forces are really complex. I laughted few times because I thought that finding a secret places in this game is much easier than finding actually your way trought mission and IT'S TRUE. Not that I hate it but let's be honest, how many games now have this much twisted level construction? Noone to very low... anyway, I love every each of levels. Those are filled with Star Wars - ever wanted to take a trip around Jabba's ship? No problem, there is mission like that! The next thing which really builds well this game are weapons - even tho there aren't any lightsabers, first weapons like blaster pistol or laser rifle are fun to use. Still, in my opinion, nothing beats Stouker Concussion Rifle - once you will get it you won't use any other weapon but be careful: it's powerful enough not only to kill enemies but poor Kyle Katarn too. Who is Kyle Katarn? Our main hero, former Imperial Stormtrooper, working as mercenary. Is he someone important? Well, because of his action there was some kind of event leading to "moon" destruction but for more you will need to play game by yourself.The graphics, music, controlls and everything feels really outdated but that doesn't mean it's bad. Years ago it was wonderful. Even the cutscenes looked amazing! As someone who loves to play old games it's still looks great but that won't be a case for everyone. I think everything gathered together builds a great Star Wars game. Sure, maybe you can't save game anytime you want like in Doom but levels aren't so long that you won't complete it at one sitting - there are some extras that will make your game a little more safe, so you won't need to start level at new when you will die. Three difficulty levels will also help you a bit to make your game fit to your taste but keep in mind, that even playing on easy won't be that easy.There is one more thing because of Star Wars being in Disney hands. "Is this canon? It's not canon anymore, right?" - does all of this talk really matter? Kyle Katarn is interesting character and it's fun to follow his story be it in games, books or comics. Dark Forces game is also fun to play, it will surely please every Star Wars fans, Doom-based games fans or everyone who just love old games. It's all that matters. I had fun playing Dark Forces and I'm sure there will be another chance to enjoy it over again.

												I enjoyed playing Dark forces. A game similar to the Doom/Quake style of gaming filled with Storm Troopers and everything you love about Star Wars makes for a very nice combo. The variation in guns meant you had a plethora to choose from so you can quickly find your style and choose your stride. The character development left a lot to be desired however and the story was just ok. The mechanics as I said before are very similar to Doom/Quake, but while this may bring nostalgia it kind of didn’t work for this game. Many times I needed to look up and down and when you can’t do it with the mouse there is a bit of a problem. Yes you can look up and down, but it is keyed to button presses. This makes the game slow down a bit as you have to either stop moving or stop looking around. Now this can be fixed easily with Xpadder probably or even a mod, but I just wanted to play my game and at the time didn’t think about it.That being said I felt the gameplay was overall solid and the story was easy to follow. Posted: December 25, 2014
												Oh man, the memories! This was one of the first video games I ever played growing up in the mid to late nineties, and it has aged like fine cheese: pungent and stinky but delicious none the less. To those who actually remember the pre-sequel Star Wars era, this game does positiviely EVERYTHING right. The guns, the enemies, the locations, and of course the characters, are all done in a manner that is faithful to the Star Wars lore. When playing this game for the first time, everything feels new yet strangely familiar, which is EXACTLY how a Star Wars game should feel. You feel like you've heard the story before, but the manner in which it is being presented this time is unique and interesting. Atmospherically, this might just be one of the greatest examples of allowing level/character set the tone. Shiny Imperial starships feature well organized corridors patrolled by brisk, professional soldiers while filthy sewers are populated by dirty, grubby looking baddies with outfits that look like they've been cobbled together from trash and scrap. Gameplay wise, the controls aren't as tight as they could be, only highlighting the fact that the platforming in this game is clunky at best. The story is no where near as long as it should be, and features only twelve missions. Despite its length, the story does do a good job of pulling you in and engaging you, even if it is a little corny even by Star Wars standards. The difficulty level is right about perfect, however. It is challenging without being impossible, yet simple enough that you rarely feel frustrated by it. That being said, the missions can feel a little bit confusing at times and you will occassionally feel like you don't know what you're supposed to do. Finally, the game's visuals haven't aged well and definately don't hold up to the standards that gamers expect out of a modern FPS. In all fairness, Datk Forces was on the cutting edge graphics-wise in 1995, and could look a lot worse. Its outdated graphical look adds a nostalgia factor to the game and give it an endearing quality that few retro indie games can match.All in all, Star Wars: Dark Forces is most definately worth a play through. Whether you're a hardcore Star Wars fan or a gamer looking to play older games for the nostalgia factor, Dark Forces will scratch your itch and scratch it good. I would even recommend this game to any potential developers out there as a good lesson in atmospheric design. A true classic and an undeniable gem in Lucasart's crown.

Posted: April 30, 2015
												A Long Time Ago in a little house in Florida far-far-away...A five year old Star Wars Fan finally got a taste of what it felt like to blast Stormtroopers and fight the Empire in a game very reminiscent of classic FPS games such as Wolfenstein 3D and Doom. Little did this boy know that this would be the beginning of a long and happy infatuation with Star Wars Games.Dark Forces might be old and it probably won't go over as well to gamers used to the HD Graphics of games such as Call of Duty or Halo but for nostalgia or introducing younger gamers with simpler and easy to play classics, Dark Forces is a definate classic for everyone to enjoy.Now you might be wondering how an old game that ran originally on DOS works on a modern computer. The good news is that the game comes built into an emulator called DOSBox which is designed to allow modern machines to run old timey classics such as Dark Forces. It works perfectly and I've not experianced any hickups. The only problems you'll run into is in the gameplay itself as some of the controls are not as modern. The controls are automatically bound to the WASD layout. The biggest problem is that if you need to look up or down, you have to hit the page up/page down keys on the the keyboard but that's the worst of your problems. Most of the blasters autoaim to some degree so you don't have to worry about being presicely on target.So big thanks to Steam and LucasArts for bringing us this Nostalgia trip. Now if you'll excuse me, I've got more of those Imperial Bucket Heads to blast.May the Force be with You.

Posted: May 4, 2015
												Dark Forces is a Doom-style shooter, meaning that mobility, reflexes and map navigation are more important skills than aiming. Simply put, you run through maze-like levels and only have to point in the general direction of an enemy to hit him (no vertical aiming, its mostly auto-aim). I didn't grow up on Doom, but I have recently been playing lots of these earlier FPS games and love that style more than the contemporary style which is more about patience and aiming.If you enjoy this style like I do and have at least a passing interest in Star Wars, I don't see why you wouldn't enjoy this game. Environments are varied, each level is very distinct and the length of the game is perfect for a game of this style. Don't be fooled by the difficulty options either, these are 90s difficulties meaning that even the Medium difficulty is going to test your Skill (The last level had me frustrated beyond belief).The game also requires you to solve some environmental puzzles which are basically just "hit this switch to open this door, and take this code and type it in there to progress"-kinds of puzzles, and they are actually not as easy as they sound, but definitely do-able without a walkthrough. Yes, you'll get stuck sometimes and won't know where to go exactly, but that's part of the fun here. It's not a perfect game to be sure, mostly because the game has plattforming sections (Again, no vertical aiming, and yet you are traversing through mountain paths... Imagine the plattforming!) but it works well enough, and the game is kind enough to give you just enough lives to let you mess up. If anything you can always use cheat codes to get you out of tight spots, but that would naturally be disgraceful.It was a joy to play through Dark Forces and it felt very rewarding to beat it on Medium difficulty. There's some replayability... I mean, you could beat it on Hard mode and find every secret there is, but I will personally not replay this game any time soon. Still, I would definitely recommend it! This is an older game that is definitely still playable. (Note: The Steam version worked without any hitch as it runs through DosBox, and it has keys bound to modern standards, which is great!  No problems whatsoever on Win 8.1 for me, so don't worry)

Posted: May 7, 2015
												Highly enjoyable. The graphics are dated to say the least, but the fast pace and satisfying feel of the blaster rifle makes up for most of it. Also, I doubt you'd even be reading a review of a 20 year old game if graphics is a dealbreaker for you. What I would like to note is the level design. The levels are very distinct and all have a unique look and feel, despite the technical limitations of the time, you rarely find yourself running down endless corridors like in Doom. Also levels are more easily navigated than other early FPS games, and keycard hunting is at a minimum. Some modern conventions for the genre might be missed, but it's a very enjoyable game despite its age.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Star Wars - Dark Forces is a First Person Shooter published by LucasArts in 1995 originally for MS-DOS and Apple Macintosh Computers. I originally got it when the Star Wars game bundle was on a massive sale on Steam. Out of the 10 games I purchased, I decided to try this one out first. Here are my first impressions of it.Graphics - 9/10: The graphics in this game are very reminiscient of Doom and Wolfenstein, both being pioneers for the FPS genre created by ID Software. It is in a pseudo-3D first-person view with pixelated textures. I give it a high score for being very revolutionary for its time, however, that doesn't mean it is perfect. The main problem is clarity. In both Doom and Wolfenstein, the graphics were clear, and you could see all of the walls, text and enemies just fine. In this game, I find that a lot of the time it is hard to see the walls and openings. This game managed to bring out the most that DOS could supply, so I give it a high score.Story - 9/10: From what I've gathered, the story of this gameis pretty much capturing data from the Death Star and bringing it back safely while fighting off Storm Troopers. This is exactly what you would expect from a Star Wars game, although I do take off a point for not much depth. The story is not particularly what you would care about, but it delivers exactly what you want for a Star Wars game.Gameplay & Controls - 5/10: As you can see from my score, the gameplay does have some serious issues. First though, let me get out all of the positives out of the way. The gameplay does give you a good sense of exploration and does a solid of job when it comes to shooting. As for the controls, they do seem standard for the average FPS and can be adjustable easily. Now let's get to the negatives. A serious issue I had with the game play is that whenever you enter a room, you are completely vulnerable to enemy attack without being able to see where they are. There have been numerous times when I go up into an elevator, then as soon as I reach the top, I have to turn around to exit while my health bar is being drained by an enemy that I cannot shoot. The game also is very unexplanatory, as I could not easily figure out all of the controls without some explanation. The controls, when you figure them out however, can be a bit weird to use if you have been previously playing a 3D FPS. You're locked into a left-right point of view, so you can not look upwards or downwards. There are flaws with the gameplay and controls, but they aren't terrible. That's why they get a medium rating.Summary: Overall, Star Wars - Dark Forces is not a perfect game, but still a good one. The gameplay could be better, but it is still a solid FPS and one of the better DOS games out there. For a price of only $5.99 without sales, I would consider it a good deal. I'm sure that there are better Star Wars games out there, but this one is still worth playing.Overall Rating: 7.6/10Hey guys! This was my first Steam Review. How do think it was? Please leave feedback, because I might do this again in the future. Thanks, and goodbye!

Posted: May 8, 2015
												To those who may dismiss this as another Doom clone...I find your lack of faith disturbing. Star Wars: Dark Forces is very much its own game. It has all the fun of a 90's run-and-gun/FPS but it adds so much more. While playing as Kyle Katarn, you'll shoot storm troopers, solve puzzles, do some platforming, use cool gear (like ice cleats and a gas mask), set explosive charges, etc. I honestly didn't expect so much depth in a game that was so pixelated. This game seems to be ahead of its time. It seems as though the people at LucasArts wanted to create a rich Star Wars adventure rather than just a cheap cash-in on the newly emerged FPS genre. And they did a very good job considering the technical limitations. Anyone who likes classic FPS games should give this one a go. Though I needed a walk-through at times to make sense of the pixelated environments, I was pleasantly surprised with how much fun I had playing Dark Forces. +Original Trilogy Star Wars Goodness+Plenty of Guns and Explosives +Puzzles+Cool Missions +Simple But Fun Story+Occasional Voice Acting-Pixelated Environments-Difficult to Navigate at Times

Posted: May 8, 2015
												This game comes highly recommended from tons of Star Wars nerds I've seen online. And... well, yeah, I enjoyed it as well. It definitely scores high on my Top Ten SW games I've played. It's a fun little Doom clone, where you play as a Rebel named Kyle Katarn as you steal the Death Star plans before the actual Star Wars film, and later uncover the secrets of a new Imperial army- The Dark Troopers. Of all the FPS' I've played, where you just fulfill missions, this game makes you feel like you're actually making progress. As you go on, you learn more about the Empire, their design of the Dark Troopers, who's in charge, where the Dark Troopers are made, what they're made of. You end up feeling like a real Rebel spy, in the end. And I like Jan Ors as a character. She helps tell you your situations, fight of TIE fighters, while you're on the ground, and you save her skin once. While Kyle may be bland himself, it's what's going on around him that I enjoyed much more.

Posted: May 7, 2015
												Highly enjoyable. The graphics are dated to say the least, but the fast pace and satisfying feel of the blaster rifle makes up for most of it. Also, I doubt you'd even be reading a review of a 20 year old game if graphics is a dealbreaker for you. What I would like to note is the level design. The levels are very distinct and all have a unique look and feel, despite the technical limitations of the time, you rarely find yourself running down endless corridors like in Doom. Also levels are more easily navigated than other early FPS games, and keycard hunting is at a minimum. Some modern conventions for the genre might be missed, but it's a very enjoyable game despite its age.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Star Wars - Dark Forces is a First Person Shooter published by LucasArts in 1995 originally for MS-DOS and Apple Macintosh Computers. I originally got it when the Star Wars game bundle was on a massive sale on Steam. Out of the 10 games I purchased, I decided to try this one out first. Here are my first impressions of it.Graphics - 9/10: The graphics in this game are very reminiscient of Doom and Wolfenstein, both being pioneers for the FPS genre created by ID Software. It is in a pseudo-3D first-person view with pixelated textures. I give it a high score for being very revolutionary for its time, however, that doesn't mean it is perfect. The main problem is clarity. In both Doom and Wolfenstein, the graphics were clear, and you could see all of the walls, text and enemies just fine. In this game, I find that a lot of the time it is hard to see the walls and openings. This game managed to bring out the most that DOS could supply, so I give it a high score.Story - 9/10: From what I've gathered, the story of this gameis pretty much capturing data from the Death Star and bringing it back safely while fighting off Storm Troopers. This is exactly what you would expect from a Star Wars game, although I do take off a point for not much depth. The story is not particularly what you would care about, but it delivers exactly what you want for a Star Wars game.Gameplay & Controls - 5/10: As you can see from my score, the gameplay does have some serious issues. First though, let me get out all of the positives out of the way. The gameplay does give you a good sense of exploration and does a solid of job when it comes to shooting. As for the controls, they do seem standard for the average FPS and can be adjustable easily. Now let's get to the negatives. A serious issue I had with the game play is that whenever you enter a room, you are completely vulnerable to enemy attack without being able to see where they are. There have been numerous times when I go up into an elevator, then as soon as I reach the top, I have to turn around to exit while my health bar is being drained by an enemy that I cannot shoot. The game also is very unexplanatory, as I could not easily figure out all of the controls without some explanation. The controls, when you figure them out however, can be a bit weird to use if you have been previously playing a 3D FPS. You're locked into a left-right point of view, so you can not look upwards or downwards. There are flaws with the gameplay and controls, but they aren't terrible. That's why they get a medium rating.Summary: Overall, Star Wars - Dark Forces is not a perfect game, but still a good one. The gameplay could be better, but it is still a solid FPS and one of the better DOS games out there. For a price of only $5.99 without sales, I would consider it a good deal. I'm sure that there are better Star Wars games out there, but this one is still worth playing.Overall Rating: 7.6/10Hey guys! This was my first Steam Review. How do think it was? Please leave feedback, because I might do this again in the future. Thanks, and goodbye!

Posted: March 11, 2015
												[note: I played through most of the game using the XL engine (http://xlengine.com/) which adds a bunch of HD stuff, but it also graphically breaks some of the puzzles a little bit.]This game is over 20 years old, having being orginally released in 28/02/95. The level design may seem a bit awkward by modern standards, and the lack of quick saves/check points is also pretty annoying. You can find respawn items in the levels that will allow you to respawn a tiny bit back from where you died, while all the enemies you killed since remain dead, but thats about it. Some people may enjoy the level of challenge this gives. The sounds and weapon effects are actually pretty great, and sound more star warsy than some of the newer games.Having originally played only JK2 and 3, this shed some light on some of the design choices of those games. Playing through the Dark Forces and Jedi Knight games in sequence (not including Mysteries of the Sith) was very interesting and gives some insight into late 90s/early 00s game design developments, both graphically and ludologically. I would say the series peaked at Jedi Knight 2: Jedi Outcast (although the JK3 Multiplayer was good), and, if you include the force unleashed duo as part of the series, hit rock bottom with TFU2.

Posted: June 27, 2015
												While this game is definitely dated, it's one of those few classics that's really worth playing even now. It's a DOOM-esque FPS with a bit of Puzzle/Platformer thrown in. The narrative is minimal, though it accomplishes what it needs to. It's probably noteable that this isn't really a "The fate of the galaxy rests on your shoulders!" story, rather you're a mercenary doing generally small-scale infiltration missions. The map design seemed a bit confusing to me at first, but you get used to it. I was flying through the final few missions and still collecting most of the secrets along the way.It's pretty short, but each mission is unique while being both challenging and fun. It's worth playing at least for a little bit to recognize the roots of the Jedi Knight series and some obvious inspirations for Shadows of the Empire.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												Doom + Star Wars with some new things (Jumping, croching, items). A favorite of my childhood, I was surprised how well this thing has aged. Graphically, it still looks very good, the cutscenes are top notch for when it was released, and level designwise, it's superior to a lot of crap we get today. The story, while a bit bland by todays standards, went above and beyond most stuff from the era (Although it should be noted it's no longer considered canon for reasons unknown to me). The game features several weapons, most of which are really enjoyable to use. Honestly the biggest flaw of the game is that it's a bit short, barring some issues I will get to in a bit. Also if you are a younger gamer, the archaic design of the game may at times confuse you, definitly go look up a guide to find or change the controls. Fans of older FPS and star wars should definitly check it out (Although you probably already have). However... Whoever put this on steam didn't try very hard, it is running on a old version of dosbox and has very very poor default settings. It will run right off the bat, but you will really want to go check out some guides on updating dosbox and changing the settings to something that makes more sense. I haven't checked GoG for this game, but I'd assume they also sell it and they probably have it set up and optimized much better, just something to consider.tl:dr : Steam version is set up poorly by default, it's a great game though.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												One of the two Star Wars video games (the other being X-Wing) that could capture the mood of the original trilogy for me. It's early enough that it didn't get rendered realistic by the all encompassing EU, it feels heroic and adventurous like the movies themselves. If X-Wing captured the dogfights perfectly, this captured the gunplay of the movies.Of course, many years passed since then, so if this is the first time you meet this game, you probably won't feel like I did. You have to accept that this is a Doom-clone (the term FPS didn't exist back then) with fake 3D, low resolution, low polygon-counts and clunky controls. It's not very accessible if you're not used to old games like this.It also has the problem that the early FPS games following Doom were a bit more detailed which was just enough to make the graphics look less clean. That might be confusing at first.

Posted: February 4, 2015
												Yes, this game is dated.  Yes, the controls are "weird".  Yes, the maps are confusing.  That said, for those of us who were fortunate to grow up in a day and age where this stuff was cutting edge, and weren't spoiled by games that assumed we were stupid and needed puzzles solved for us, this game still holds up as an awesome testiment to FPS history.Noted as being "Doom with Star Wars Graphics", Dark Forces took gaming to the next level.  The voice acting was simply superb for the day, as was the cutscene detail.  We were drawn into the galaxy of Star Wars and told a story that closely ties to the origional movie trilogy (before Jar Jar).  You were made to feel as though you had a part in those movies, without actually being thrown into them.  This great story would be continued in Dark Forces II, but we're not here to talk about that.For nostalgia purposes this game brings us back to a time when gaming was still searching for it's niche.  it's a time when "WASD" wasn't yet tied to a mouse as the "accepted" way to control a character.  You had to have both hands on the keyboard and learn how to multi-task your fingers, a skill that the youth these days would probably find confusing and too complicated.Level design in Dark Forces, easily the biggest complaint against the game, was very well done in my opinion.  Every part of the map is used in some way.  It's either a place to pick up more shields and ammo, or has a switch, or has an item you need, or has a secret you've yet to uncover.  There is no wasted space, and it's up to you to figure out what to do with it.  Sure, you can run around a map for 15 minutes trying to figure out the next step.  For those who are used to today's games leading them around by the hand it can be a little frustrating.  For those of us who grew up with these games, solving the challenge can be quite rewarding and we wouldn't have it any other way.Dark Forces was designed back in 1995, where the standard was DOS based gaming.  That said, in order for this game to function it's packed seamlessly with DOSBox.  I, personally, have never had a problem with games that are bundled in this manor.  The game is a perfectly emulated version of it's former glory.  There isn't any configuring required, unless you're one of those stubborn control freaks who needs everything to operate THEIR way.The only hick-up I ran into was remembering that at the end of each level, when your mission is complete, you have to hit ESC in order to move on to the next level.  That information was included in the origional guide (as I recall), and will eventually pop-up in the game if you spend a long time waiting for the level to end by itself.  It's a minor issue that's resolved at the end of the first mission, and as such doesn't change my recommnedation.If you've been spoiled by the high-end graphics and hand-holding of today's games then by all means avoid this title because it's not for you.  If you, like me, grew up with games like Doom, Heretic, Hexen, Decent, and Duke Nukem 3D then this is a MUST HAVE due to it's awesome storyline and great nostalgic value.  Its a testiment to early gaming and definately worth every penny.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Star Wars: Dark Forces, is a old, odd, game. When I purchased it on Steam, several years ago now... I really didn't know what I was buying. Yes, I knew it was a Star Wars game, but the main thing that had me eyeballing it, was it's ridiculous cheep price. It was $0.99. One of the first things that surprised me was that it was an older game, Dark Forces came out in 1995 for MS-Dos. Which is why this game uses a pre-programed version of Dos-box to run the game on modern machines. I've played it on several computers, it seems to run just fine. Dark Forces is the first in the Jedi Knight game series, you play as Kyle Katarn, a young mercenary, a cross between Han Solo and Luke Skywalker. In the future games Kyle grows to become a Jedi Knight, but in this game he's just a mercenary. Gameplay is fine, think of a Star Wars meets Duke Nukem 3D. Dark Forces falls in from the time where 3D shooters weren’t quiet all 3D yet, a 2.5D pixel wonderland where you explore and take down stormtroopers and the evil dark stormtoopers. Do you have a lightsaber? Nope. But you really don't need to, Dark Forces has you play as a one man army. You're not a Jedi. You're a hired gun, and honestly it's better this way. You're not this over powered superman with force powers, mowing down enemies. You're a dude turned against the empire. You're not in it to be noble, you're out for vengeance. This could have turned into an interesting series, you have this character go deeper and deeper to the darkside basically by killing stormtroopers for the wrong reasons, yet fighting for the right of the rebellion. Instead, they dropped that, gave you a lightsaber, and called you a Jedi Knight in the sequel. Dark Forces is an older game, don't expect to be wowed by the story or gameplay. You might be in for a shock to discover, much like myself that the Theme from Star Wars is played from a Midi version. But that's because its from that odd period of time. No, FMV... that’s for the sequel. If you're a Star Wars fan, you'll want to play this, and probably the rest of the Jedi Knight series.If you're like me, and really didn't know what this game was about. It's a fun doom-like game. If you wait for it to go on sale for about .99 cents. I say give it a shot, I did and got a lot out of it. If Doom/Duke Nukem games really aren't your thing, I'd pass it up.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												Star Wars: Dark Forces was written off as a "Doom clone" on release in spite of its critical acclaim,Indeed, it is hard to look at the game and not draw a parallel with the legendary shooter.However, Dark Forces made a lot of innovations on the formula that is common place in shooters of today. Dark Forces innovated with essential features like the ability to crouch, jump as well as to look up and down.This game also made rounds for its ability to feature true room-over-room level designs with rooms intertwining within each other in impressive, multi-story displays of architecture.Dark Forces also shot for a grounded, more realistic look taken right out of the movies in spite of the graphical shortcomings of the era. This was made possible with the game's wide selection of  level tiles that were rarely repeated.Another aspect that helped the unique feel of each level was that no level was simply about traversing from A to B. Instead, you got a detailed mission briefing that gave you multiple goals that had to be seen through before heading out. These goals could be things like turning on the power of an area, planting explosives or infiltrating an imperial stronghold for information before making it back to your ship in one piece. All of these innovations results in a shooter that was way ahead of its time.Dark Forces is a truly unique title that shouldn't be missed by FPS fans and Star Wars fans alike.As a fan of the latter but not the former, I was very happy that I decided to play this game.Be aware that this game comes installed with an outdated version of DOSbox that should be updated and manually configured before play. Luckily, there are users on the steam forums that can guide you through the process if you are unsure of what to do.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												One of the two Star Wars video games (the other being X-Wing) that could capture the mood of the original trilogy for me. It's early enough that it didn't get rendered realistic by the all encompassing EU, it feels heroic and adventurous like the movies themselves. If X-Wing captured the dogfights perfectly, this captured the gunplay of the movies.Of course, many years passed since then, so if this is the first time you meet this game, you probably won't feel like I did. You have to accept that this is a Doom-clone (the term FPS didn't exist back then) with fake 3D, low resolution, low polygon-counts and clunky controls. It's not very accessible if you're not used to old games like this.It also has the problem that the early FPS games following Doom were a bit more detailed which was just enough to make the graphics look less clean. That might be confusing at first.

The story is all breezy, and involves espionage for the Rebel Alliance, mostly about the Death Star, in advance of the plot of the first Star Wars (the real first one, not Episode 1). That's about it. The game is too terribly long, but not too short either. Basically get it if you enjoy nostalgia, both in Star Wars EU and very early shooters, and it is on-sale cheap, or part of a pack.

Posted: August 28, 2016
												This remains, to my mind, the finest Star Wars game ever produced. Having played most of them at one point or another, I feel justified in my opinion.This was one of the early, first generation of 3D games, and I credit it (along with Timothy Zahn) as being the reason Star Wars resurged as it has since 1995. Even today, it is still marvelously fun and fiendishly difficult. Try to get through it at highest difficulty, and enjoy. ALso enjoy the glorious midi-style music and the pixel art cutscenes that are still of a high quality even today. There is nothing to not enjoy about this game - and indeed the rest of the Jedi Knight series. Now if only Rogue One wouldn't retcon its existence....

Posted: March 30
												Star wars Dark Forces was certaintly great for it's time. Pack with a whooping 14 levels with great level designs and albeit hard puzzles (I had to watch a few guides to get me through some levels) it was certainly entertaining. It was the first game on DOS that we are able to look up and down. However, since I'm so used to using the mouse to look up and down, using the keyboard to do that prove a bit tedious. Luckily this game has auto aim, so it helped tremendously. Story wise, It's not so much and not very emphasised. You play as Kyle Katarn, working for the rebelion. You stole the plans for the death star with ease, and later your entire mission will be to slow down the production of the dark troopers. Currently, this story is no longer canon but before episode 7 came out, this is a great bridge to close the loophole of the destruction of the death star. Overall, I do reccomend to give this game a try if you're really patient.

Posted: December 2, 2015
Recommendation level:|-|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|▓▓▓▓▓▓|+|I grew up playing the best shooters from the 90s like the Doom, Quake, Wolfenstein, Duke Nukem, Blood and Redneck Rampage games, but I only recently had the chance to try out this gem. 20 years after it was originally released Dark Forces is still one of the best shooters ever made, and definitely one of the finest Star Wars game out there.Its graphics are the usual retro pixelated stuff with sprite objects and simplistic 3d environment. Though, it is not as shiny as nowadays action pieces, still the style and detail it presents is immersive and nice to look at. The story is good enough for a shooter, telling various information before every mission and showing cutscenes which are similar those seen in old LucasArts adventure titles, so the quality standard is high. The gameplay is fast-paced and refined making progression through the levels fun. There is a set of well-designed maps which are filled with shortcuts and secret areas allowing and rewarding exploration and adding replay value. The whole game feels good to play with all its mechanics, and never feels clunky as most older games do.Overall, everyone who are interested in retro shooters should try DF along with Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy. There is no way that these games could disappoint anyone.MY OPINION: 8.5/10 (EXCELLENT)Graphics: 8/10World Design: 9/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 8/10Replay Value: 8/10

While Kyle Katarn and his story of stealing Death Star Plans and destroying the dark troopers is no longer canon, this is a fun adventure in the Star Wars universe.
