Posted: April 19, 2015
												This is a Doom Clone set in the Star Wars universe.Pros:It has all of the good traits that Doom Clones have, such as no cover, more than two weapon slots,  and non-linear maps.The gunplay feels solid and gunning down enemies is satisfying.The story is pretty good for a FPS released only a year and a few months after Doom II. It involves really good voice acting for the time period and some cut scenes that I imagine looked pretty good in 1995 but now have a certain retro charm to them.The soundtrack really makes the most of it's MIDI music, and most of the songs still hold up today, especially the opening song. Unless you don't like MIDI music, in which case you probably won't like this game's music.The environment is well designed, and does a good job capturing the feel of wherever the level is supposed to be set. This is an area  that I always thought that Doom I and II frequently fell short, so this is rather big deal.ConsThis is a FPS with LIMITED LIVES. You get three in the beginning, and you can find more hidden in the levels. This "feature" is definitely going to make a few people not interested in this game anymore, but it isn't as big of a deal as it sounds.You can't save your game mid-level. Even Wolfenstein 3D had that feature, and it also had limited lives, so I can't see why they didn't put that in this game. As with many early Doom Clones/FPSs, to aim up and down, you have to press Page Up and Page Down.  However when you aim at an enemy on a higher level than you are aiming, the game automatically detects that you are aiming at the enemy and your blaster shots automatically aim up. Sometimes this works, sometimes it doesn't. However, this isn't that big of a deal in the end. Fortunately, the game supports mouse control for looking left and right.Like other Doom Clones, the game is rather pixelated. However, you can use XL Engine (a source port of this game and several others) to fix this, as well as the aiming up/down issue.Easily the biggest problem present in  this game, as well as many other Doom Clones, is that the non-linear levels act as a double-edged sword. On one hand, it can be quite liberating to play a fairly non-linear FPS, as you aren't being pushed down a corridor like in Call of Duty. On the other hand, it can be difficult at times to figure out where you are supposed to go next. This can result in a frustrating "Where do I go now?" feeling  compounded by the fact that you usually aren't doing a lot of shooting while looking where to go next. Bottom LineIf you are searching for a retro FPS to wash the foul taste of today's ultra-linear FPSs, this is a game for you.If you like Star Wars, I can't  recommend this game to you unless you also like retro first-person-shooters. Honestly, this type of game is rather dated in some ways, so it isn't for everybody. But if you do like Star Wars and retro first-person shooters, you should buy this right now.Similar games:Wolfenstein 3DSpear of DestinyDoomDoom IIHereticHexenDuke Nukem 3DRise of the TriadBlake StoneRedneck RampageBloodTIP: Press F5 to turn on a flashlight. This seriously helps in some of the darker levels.

Posted: February 13, 2016
												I enjoyed playing Dark forces. A game similar to the Doom/Quake style of gaming filled with Storm Troopers and everything you love about Star Wars makes for a very nice combo. The variation in guns meant you had a plethora to choose from so you can quickly find your style and choose your stride. The character development left a lot to be desired however and the story was just ok. The mechanics as I said before are very similar to Doom/Quake, but while this may bring nostalgia it kind of didn’t work for this game. Many times I needed to look up and down and when you can’t do it with the mouse there is a bit of a problem. Yes you can look up and down, but it is keyed to button presses. This makes the game slow down a bit as you have to either stop moving or stop looking around. Now this can be fixed easily with Xpadder probably or even a mod, but I just wanted to play my game and at the time didn’t think about it.That being said I felt the gameplay was overall solid and the story was easy to follow. The map was a bit hard to navigate and I did get lost a few times, but if you take your time and slow down, or do what I did and look up a play-through, you can make it through. Also punching giant lizards, sorry I don’t know what they are called bear with me I’m a Star Wars fan, but I don’t act like I have a PhD, was a lot of fun!I give the game a solid 7. It didn’t wow me, but it kept me playing and that deserves a solid score.

Posted: July 18, 2012
												Oh man. This was the FIRST PC game I owned as a child. Like, the first that I had that I could call my own, and take with me from my moms to my grandmas and install and play because it was MINE and I could take it wherever I felt like. I played this game over and over and over again as a kid. It's basically Doom meets Star Wars. It's not too hard, not too easy, yet it does have those moments where you're wandering around for an hour not knowing where to go, only to find there was a secret staircase you missed because you didn't look behind you when you were walking through that hallway. Attention to detail plays a huge role in this game. You have to pay attention to your surroundings or you may as well just give up. Like Doom? Like Star Wars? Like DOS games? This is a good game to buy.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												This is really the first game that made me feel like I was actually in the universe of Star Wars. Playing this as a kid on my stepdad's DOS PC was absolutely amazing. When I booted this game up, I got that wave of nostalgia.However, it wasn't long before the reality of this game's aging set in. Lightly put, it plays like *ss. I can't believe I beat this when I was like, five.HOWEVER, I still recommend people purchase this game; the reason being that some kind soul created the XLEngine for playing DOS shooters on modern Windows PCs. After modifying the game's files to play on DarkXL, it runs like a dream. Resolutions that don't look like vomit, full mouse aim control, and complete control swapping abilities (without having to go through DosBox's ridiculous menus and settings) really catapult this game into the modern era, to the point where it feels even better than I remember.If you're willing to put in the time to configure the game properly, it'll pay off in spades. This game is definitely a classic worth revisiting.

Recommendation level:|-|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|░░░░░░|▓▓▓▓▓▓|+|I grew up playing the best shooters from the 90s like the Doom, Quake, Wolfenstein, Duke Nukem, Blood and Redneck Rampage games, but I only recently had the chance to try out this gem. 20 years after it was originally released Dark Forces is still one of the best shooters ever made, and definitely one of the finest Star Wars game out there.Its graphics are the usual retro pixelated stuff with sprite objects and simplistic 3d environment. Though, it is not as shiny as nowadays action pieces, still the style and detail it presents is immersive and nice to look at. The story is good enough for a shooter, telling various information before every mission and showing cutscenes which are similar those seen in old LucasArts adventure titles, so the quality standard is high. The gameplay is fast-paced and refined making progression through the levels fun. There is a set of well-designed maps which are filled with shortcuts and secret areas allowing and rewarding exploration and adding replay value. The whole game feels good to play with all its mechanics, and never feels clunky as most older games do.Overall, everyone who are interested in retro shooters should try DF along with Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy. There is no way that these games could disappoint anyone.MY OPINION: 8.5/10 (EXCELLENT)Graphics: 8/10World Design: 9/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 8/10Replay Value: 8/10

Posted: February 13, 2016
												I enjoyed playing Dark forces. A game similar to the Doom/Quake style of gaming filled with Storm Troopers and everything you love about Star Wars makes for a very nice combo. The variation in guns meant you had a plethora to choose from so you can quickly find your style and choose your stride. The character development left a lot to be desired however and the story was just ok. The mechanics as I said before are very similar to Doom/Quake, but while this may bring nostalgia it kind of didn’t work for this game. Many times I needed to look up and down and when you can’t do it with the mouse there is a bit of a problem. Yes you can look up and down, but it is keyed to button presses. This makes the game slow down a bit as you have to either stop moving or stop looking around. Now this can be fixed easily with Xpadder probably or even a mod, but I just wanted to play my game and at the time didn’t think about it.That being said I felt the gameplay was overall solid and the story was easy to follow. The map was a bit hard to navigate and I did get lost a few times, but if you take your time and slow down, or do what I did and look up a play-through, you can make it through. Also punching giant lizards, sorry I don’t know what they are called bear with me I’m a Star Wars fan, but I don’t act like I have a PhD, was a lot of fun!I give the game a solid 7. It didn’t wow me, but it kept me playing and that deserves a solid score.

Posted: February 12, 2016
												Star Wars - Doom, Doom: Star Wars... no matter how you would call it, Dark Forces is really amazing game.Dark Forces wasn't my first Star Wars game. Played it for first time probably around Star Wars Episode 1 film premiere because it made to want to play everything with "Star Wars" in name. The only thing I was wondering when I will got lightsaber and have some cool Jedi fights but at the time, sadly, I was disappointed to see that I won't use one in this game. Many years later, in 2016, I wanted to replay it. To be honest, when it would be my first time playing, I would stop playing it few times. Why? First of all, nowaday gamers will have trouble finding their way to finish missions. Levels in Dark Forces are really complex. I laughted few times because I thought that finding a secret places in this game is much easier than finding actually your way trought mission and IT'S TRUE. Not that I hate it but let's be honest, how many games now have this much twisted level construction? Noone to very low... anyway, I love every each of levels. Those are filled with Star Wars - ever wanted to take a trip around Jabba's ship? No problem, there is mission like that! The next thing which really builds well this game are weapons - even tho there aren't any lightsabers, first weapons like blaster pistol or laser rifle are fun to use. Still, in my opinion, nothing beats Stouker Concussion Rifle - once you will get it you won't use any other weapon but be careful: it's powerful enough not only to kill enemies but poor Kyle Katarn too. Who is Kyle Katarn? Our main hero, former Imperial Stormtrooper, working as mercenary. Is he someone important? Well, because of his action there was some kind of event leading to "moon" destruction but for more you will need to play game by yourself.The graphics, music, controlls and everything feels really outdated but that doesn't mean it's bad. Years ago it was wonderful. Even the cutscenes looked amazing! As someone who loves to play old games it's still looks great but that won't be a case for everyone. I think everything gathered together builds a great Star Wars game. Sure, maybe you can't save game anytime you want like in Doom but levels aren't so long that you won't complete it at one sitting - there are some extras that will make your game a little more safe, so you won't need to start level at new when you will die. Three difficulty levels will also help you a bit to make your game fit to your taste but keep in mind, that even playing on easy won't be that easy.There is one more thing because of Star Wars being in Disney hands. "Is this canon? It's not canon anymore, right?" - does all of this talk really matter? Kyle Katarn is interesting character and it's fun to follow his story be it in games, books or comics. Dark Forces game is also fun to play, it will surely please every Star Wars fans, Doom-based games fans or everyone who just love old games. It's all that matters. I had fun playing Dark Forces and I'm sure there will be another chance to enjoy it over again.

Posted: April 19, 2015
												This is a Doom Clone set in the Star Wars universe.Pros:It has all of the good traits that Doom Clones have, such as no cover, more than two weapon slots,  and non-linear maps.The gunplay feels solid and gunning down enemies is satisfying.The story is pretty good for a FPS released only a year and a few months after Doom II. It involves really good voice acting for the time period and some cut scenes that I imagine looked pretty good in 1995 but now have a certain retro charm to them.The soundtrack really makes the most of it's MIDI music, and most of the songs still hold up today, especially the opening song. Unless you don't like MIDI music, in which case you probably won't like this game's music.The environment is well designed, and does a good job capturing the feel of wherever the level is supposed to be set. This is an area  that I always thought that Doom I and II frequently fell short, so this is rather big deal.ConsThis is a FPS with LIMITED LIVES. You get three in the beginning, and you can find more hidden in the levels. This "feature" is definitely going to make a few people not interested in this game anymore, but it isn't as big of a deal as it sounds.You can't save your game mid-level. Even Wolfenstein 3D had that feature, and it also had limited lives, so I can't see why they didn't put that in this game. As with many early Doom Clones/FPSs, to aim up and down, you have to press Page Up and Page Down.  However when you aim at an enemy on a higher level than you are aiming, the game automatically detects that you are aiming at the enemy and your blaster shots automatically aim up. Sometimes this works, sometimes it doesn't. However, this isn't that big of a deal in the end. Fortunately, the game supports mouse control for looking left and right.Like other Doom Clones, the game is rather pixelated. However, you can use XL Engine (a source port of this game and several others) to fix this, as well as the aiming up/down issue.Easily the biggest problem present in  this game, as well as many other Doom Clones, is that the non-linear levels act as a double-edged sword. On one hand, it can be quite liberating to play a fairly non-linear FPS, as you aren't being pushed down a corridor like in Call of Duty. On the other hand, it can be difficult at times to figure out where you are supposed to go next. This can result in a frustrating "Where do I go now?" feeling  compounded by the fact that you usually aren't doing a lot of shooting while looking where to go next. Bottom LineIf you are searching for a retro FPS to wash the foul taste of today's ultra-linear FPSs, this is a game for you.If you like Star Wars, I can't  recommend this game to you unless you also like retro first-person-shooters. Honestly, this type of game is rather dated in some ways, so it isn't for everybody. But if you do like Star Wars and retro first-person shooters, you should buy this right now.Similar games:Wolfenstein 3DSpear of DestinyDoomDoom IIHereticHexenDuke Nukem 3DRise of the TriadBlake StoneRedneck RampageBloodTIP: Press F5 to turn on a flashlight. This seriously helps in some of the darker levels.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Star Wars - Dark Forces is a First Person Shooter published by LucasArts in 1995 originally for MS-DOS and Apple Macintosh Computers. I originally got it when the Star Wars game bundle was on a massive sale on Steam. Out of the 10 games I purchased, I decided to try this one out first. Here are my first impressions of it.Graphics - 9/10: The graphics in this game are very reminiscient of Doom and Wolfenstein, both being pioneers for the FPS genre created by ID Software. It is in a pseudo-3D first-person view with pixelated textures. I give it a high score for being very revolutionary for its time, however, that doesn't mean it is perfect. The main problem is clarity. In both Doom and Wolfenstein, the graphics were clear, and you could see all of the walls, text and enemies just fine. In this game, I find that a lot of the time it is hard to see the walls and openings. This game managed to bring out the most that DOS could supply, so I give it a high score.Story - 9/10: From what I've gathered, the story of this gameis pretty much capturing data from the Death Star and bringing it back safely while fighting off Storm Troopers. This is exactly what you would expect from a Star Wars game, although I do take off a point for not much depth. The story is not particularly what you would care about, but it delivers exactly what you want for a Star Wars game.Gameplay & Controls - 5/10: As you can see from my score, the gameplay does have some serious issues. First though, let me get out all of the positives out of the way. The gameplay does give you a good sense of exploration and does a solid of job when it comes to shooting. As for the controls, they do seem standard for the average FPS and can be adjustable easily. Now let's get to the negatives. A serious issue I had with the game play is that whenever you enter a room, you are completely vulnerable to enemy attack without being able to see where they are. There have been numerous times when I go up into an elevator, then as soon as I reach the top, I have to turn around to exit while my health bar is being drained by an enemy that I cannot shoot. The game also is very unexplanatory, as I could not easily figure out all of the controls without some explanation. The controls, when you figure them out however, can be a bit weird to use if you have been previously playing a 3D FPS. You're locked into a left-right point of view, so you can not look upwards or downwards. There are flaws with the gameplay and controls, but they aren't terrible. That's why they get a medium rating.Summary: Overall, Star Wars - Dark Forces is not a perfect game, but still a good one. The gameplay could be better, but it is still a solid FPS and one of the better DOS games out there. For a price of only $5.99 without sales, I would consider it a good deal. I'm sure that there are better Star Wars games out there, but this one is still worth playing.Overall Rating: 7.6/10Hey guys! This was my first Steam Review. How do think it was? Please leave feedback, because I might do this again in the future. Thanks, and goodbye!

Posted: April 30, 2015
												A Long Time Ago in a little house in Florida far-far-away...A five year old Star Wars Fan finally got a taste of what it felt like to blast Stormtroopers and fight the Empire in a game very reminiscent of classic FPS games such as Wolfenstein 3D and Doom. Little did this boy know that this would be the beginning of a long and happy infatuation with Star Wars Games.Dark Forces might be old and it probably won't go over as well to gamers used to the HD Graphics of games such as Call of Duty or Halo but for nostalgia or introducing younger gamers with simpler and easy to play classics, Dark Forces is a definate classic for everyone to enjoy.Now you might be wondering how an old game that ran originally on DOS works on a modern computer. The good news is that the game comes built into an emulator called DOSBox which is designed to allow modern machines to run old timey classics such as Dark Forces. It works perfectly and I've not experianced any hickups. The only problems you'll run into is in the gameplay itself as some of the controls are not as modern. The controls are automatically bound to the WASD layout. The biggest problem is that if you need to look up or down, you have to hit the page up/page down keys on the the keyboard but that's the worst of your problems. Most of the blasters autoaim to some degree so you don't have to worry about being presicely on target.So big thanks to Steam and LucasArts for bringing us this Nostalgia trip. Now if you'll excuse me, I've got more of those Imperial Bucket Heads to blast.May the Force be with You.

												This is a solidly build game.  They incorporated a real story into the game, cut scenes, mission briefings, dialog, something most 90's FPS games just couldn't manage.  And it's done well.  Your charater's a bit overpowered, but it's an FPS, what do you expect?  The level design really shines in a lot of areas, with some fendish puzzles in places.  That may be a negative as some areas of the game will take you a while to figure out how to advance.  There's also not a whole lot of variety in the enemies or weapons, most are just different versions of the same thing. Posted: March 30
												Star wars Dark Forces was certaintly great for it's time. Pack with a whooping 14 levels with great level designs and albeit hard puzzles (I had to watch a few guides to get me through some levels) it was certainly entertaining. It was the first game on DOS that we are able to look up and down. However, since I'm so used to using the mouse to look up and down, using the keyboard to do that prove a bit tedious. Luckily this game has auto aim, so it helped tremendously. Story wise, It's not so much and not very emphasised. You play as Kyle Katarn, working for the rebelion. You stole the plans for the death star with ease, and later your entire mission will be to slow down the production of the dark troopers. Currently, this story is no longer canon but before episode 7 came out, this is a great bridge to close the loophole of the destruction of the death star. Overall, I do reccomend to give this game a try if you're really patient.

Posted: October 11, 2016
												Ya like Star Wars? Do ya also like Doom? Well how 'bout Doom with Star Wars in it? Sounds good? Ok, have fun.That's basically all there is to the game, and yet it still pulls it off so well. This game follows the adventures of fan-favorite Kyle Katarn, former Imperial Officer turned Rebel mercenary after learning his father was murdered by the Empire and who, in the expanded universe, was the actual person who stole the Death Star plans. That's what the first mission is about, taking place between Episodes III and IV, just before the takeover of the Tantive IV in A New Hope. The subsequent levels deal with a new threat to the Rebel Alliance and the Galaxy: The Dark Trooper Initiative. Kyle is tasked with finding out what it is and putting a stop to it.Along the way you'll find familar and not-so-familiar Star Wars weapons, like blaster rifles, thermal detonators, and a big♥♥♥♥♥Dark Trooper weapon that is suposedly too heavy for a human to lift, but, oh well, I guess you can lift it after all.The sound and graphics are really good for a 1995 DOS game, and the graphics shine in the cutscenes and look pretty fluid. In game it might be a little harder to see enemies from a distance as they dissolve into a mess of pixels, but the game still distinctively looks and sounds like a Star Wars game, as you will hear the familiar sounds of blasers being fired and hear the cries of dying Stormtroopers and Imperial Officers.In terms of difficulty, this game can be played on easy with a challenge. Not in the form of combat, but in knowing where the hell you're supposed to be going. And the enemies aren't pushovers like in the movies. Stormtroopers will regularly hit you before you can hit them, but there's so much freaking health and shield supplies lying around that the threat of death is rare, and you can pick up extra lives in common enough spaces, so getting a Game Over is pretty rare (and disappointing, because you must suck at this game to get a Game Over.)Overall, Star Wars Dark Forces is a pretty cool game, but I can't see myself playing this very often. It's not a bad game, far from it, but I can't see myself choosing to play this over Doom very often. I'd still recommend picking this game up though, you won't have a bad time, I swear on my life or may God strike me down.

Posted: July 13, 2015
												A Pretty good 90s shooter and Star Wars game. If you've played Doom, Duke 3D, Shadow Warrior, ect, you'll feel right at home. Its core gameplay is pretty standard shooter fare, you're a walking armory and you shoot a bunch of stuff until it all dies or gets destroyed. The shooting itself is great fun, giving you access to a bunch of recognizable Star Wars arsenal, along with some weapons whipped up for this game specifically. This game does change the shooter formula up somewhat though by introducing more objective based missions and having a pretty decent overarching story. The levels are also much more maze-like and have a good number of puzzles compared to most classic shooters. You also can't save during individual levels, but the game has a lives system to kind of compensate for the difficulty of finishing a whole level in one go.Unfortunately, because its a DOS era game on Steam it needs some tweaking to get working properly. It does "work" out of the box so to speak, however it looks worse than it should and runs terrible on top of it. Luckily, there are several guides that are easy to follow on the steam forums that should fix most of the issues it has. I'd also recommend disabling the steam overlay for it, as it sometimes causes graphic issues. If you are willing to put in the extra work though, it's a great game. Highly recommended for fans of shooters and Star Wars.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												The story of Kyle Katarn begins here in the first triligy of the dark forces series. Before he was a jedi Battle master for the new jedi order Commander Katarn was a mercenery for the Rebel Allaince and is tasked with the destruction of  the Dark Trooper project (In short he's pretty much a badass, but if you've ever played the Jedi knight series the entire game of dark forces is a cakewalk compared to what he'll be doing afterward)Pros: Fun shooter for it's time it came out in 1995, The sound effects are really good for it's time as well, unlike the original Doom you can look up and down you can even jump, you also have a verity of weapons, the music and cinematices are awesome for it's time after all Scott Larwence is a great Darth Vader.Cons: Some missions have puzzles that are too challenging you will get lost if you don't know what you are doing you'll even die, The game could also be a bit short it took me 9 hours to beat but that's because I've played this before there even was steam, but the number one thing about this is the fact that sewer levels are really a nightmare and there will be more of them throughout the game.

Posted: January 2
												Yes, it's an old game, but the "retro" appreciators out there will understand best. I played this when it was new in 1995 and could not get enough. I remember thinking it was a Star Wars skinned version of Doom. How graphics and rendering technology has advanced us to a level of “spoiled” I never imagined back in the good ol' 90's!If you've been a gamer since the early days (yes, I know that is relative), as well as a Star Wars fan, then I certainly recommend this “blast from the past” for your nostalgic pleasure. Even more contemporary gamers may find some enjoyment in playing title over 20 years old. Be warned modern day gamers used to that “free look” with your mouse, it doesn't happen here. I'm not going to list a bunch of pros and cons, as this game predates most of today's standards. Frankly, you either like it, or you don't.Cheers

 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Star Wars - Dark Forces is a game developed and originally published by LucasArts and now published by Walt Disney InteractiveYes, it's an old game, but the "retro" appreciators out there will understand best. If you've been a gamer since the early days, as well as a Star Wars fan, then I certainly recommend this “blast from the past” for your nostalgic pleasure. Posted: January 2
												Kyle Katarn and I stole the plans to the Death Star twenty years before Jyn Orso got there.Like so many things associated with Star Wars, it's hard for me to not to have a view of Dark Forces that is not tinted with nostalgia but the recent release of Rogue One inspired me to revisit the game to see how well it held up.Outside of Star Wars, the other main point of reference is, of course, Doom.  A 1990s FPS was judged based on what it did well or poorly in comparison to the latest id game, to the extent that the genre was known as Doom-clones rather than first person shooters.Dark Forces was a truly excellent Doom-clone.  Despite not having true 3D levels, the developers were able to hack together a system that gave the levels a verticality that Doom just didn't have.  Rooms could be located on top of one another, and the result was anything from maze-like prison complexes built into cliffsides to simple things like gaps you could jump over and bridges you could walk both over and under.  It was the kind of leap forward that sounds so trivial after it was done, it's hard to imagine games without it.  The improved technology would not have mattered if Dark Forces didn't feel like a Star Wars game though.  iMuse was a system that dynamically mixed the music with the rise and fall of in-game action that had been used successfully in previous LucasArts games.  As with X-Wing and TIE Fighter it sounded fantastic when applied to Star Wars themes.  Voice acting and a handful of cutscenes let the game tell a simple but functional story, itself a somewhat innovative idea for a mid-90s FPS.Is it worth playing outside of nostalgia or as a history lesson in FPS design?   Many of the mechanics are simple by today's standards.  Enemies shoot at you or walk around slightly aimlessly, and while there is a good range of weapons available to the player, the gunplay is very basic.  Lives are used instead of a save or checkpoint system, which leads to an occasional need to restart the level when you fall to your death too many times or die against the handful of actually difficult enemies.  Ultimately though it's impressive that the game has aged as well as it has, and with the use of a graphics mod like DarkXL, it's still eminently playable.

Posted: January 2
												One of my favourite classic DOS shooters. Some interesting environments (a variety of outdoor and indoor locations, great music (including dynamic music that changes to the situation - unlike many other shooters of its time) and pretty fun gameplay with interesting puzzles. Although a few puzzles can be a little tricky (seems to be a Lucas Arts thing at times), they're satisfying to work and complete nevertheless. Worth a playthrough; while it doesn't include any "Jedi Knight' elements, it's still a decent enough game nevertheless.

												One of my favourite classic DOS shooters. Some interesting environments (a variety of outdoor and indoor locations, great music (including dynamic music that changes to the situation - unlike many other shooters of its time) and pretty fun gameplay with interesting puzzles. Posted: April 21, 2011
												If you're wondering what is the earliest and expansive Star Wars game that has depth and based on orginial stories and locations, then look no further than Dark Forces. This series introduced a lot in Star Wars Expansive Universe and it used The Death Star plans heist before Rouge One.What will you like:+ It follows the gameplay standards which were set by the original DOOM. If you loved DOOM, you will enjoy Dark Forces.+ Awesome original soundtrack that is inspired by Star Wars trilogy. It also dynamically changes when going in and out of action (LucasArts iMuse engine)+ Complex level designs with lots of verticality involved.+ You are able to crouch, jump, sprint, use a flashlight, and using alt-fire for each weapon.+ Interesting set of Star Wars weapons (no light saber though).+ Animated Cutscenes.+ Variety of level environment designs. There are icy planets, red planets, sewer level, imperial bases, imperial space station, mountains and so on...What you might dislike:- This version has low res graphics and music quality. I recall that the PS1 version was sharper and had better music.- No free mouse look. You have to press page-up or page-down to see up and down, which you will do when you need to check for edges of a platform before jumping.Who should buy this game?If you like classic FPS games like Doom or Duke Nukem and you are into Star Wars, you will definitly like this game.

Posted: February 19
												It's a great game. If you like Star Wars and Doom you'll like this. There's lots of variety in the level missions, and the weapons feel satisfying to shoot. My biggest complaint though is that you can't look up or down with the mouse, but the game requires you to do it pretty often. You'll probably want to rebind the look up/down buttons in dosbox to something closer to the walk keys.Other than that I think it's aged surprisingly well. Definitely worth playing

Posted: January 14
												Dark Forces is often compared to Doom, but it's definitely got its own vibe going on. While Doom is run and gun action, Dark Forces throws some map-based puzzles your way. Some of these work really well and are genuinely interesting while others are exceptionally tedious and annoying. The detention center level in particular features a veryfrustrating situation that forced me to spend a few bucks calling the LucasArts hint line in the mid-90s.With that caveat in mind, this is a fairly immersive experience in the Star Wars universe (as immersive as things got in 1995). You get to explore a star destroyer, imperial bases, and even Coruscant pre-Phantom Menace. Upon release, this game offered a lot of experiences that were a Star Wars fan's wet dream - all through the eyes of bad♥♥♥♥♥mercenary Kyle Katarn.I do feel like this game has aged better than its sequel Jedi Knight (1997) in terms of playability. Something about the sprite-based enemies and pseudo 3D experience offers a kind of retro charm that makes this easy to pick up and play.If you enjoy the Star Wars universe and 90s first-person shooters, I would say this is worth the cost of entry. It is a 22 year old game though, so the sometimes-floaty controls and overall aesthetic will likely be off-putting to the folks who didn't play this back in the day.
